hints.content:
Lets figure out the factors for the rows and columns. Then we can multiply to find the missing values.

![The same table as above, marked with a multiplication symbol.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6d159bad88a6cbd02e4e8a35663b7a9305101e44)

$50 \stackrel{\blueE{+10}}{\longrightarrow} 60 \stackrel{\blueE{+10}}{\longrightarrow} 70 $

The factor for the third column is $\blueE{10}$.

![The same table as above, with the third column labeled 10.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d556d02ace9d6e0bf5adccb86590255e2bf2fe22)

The factor for each column of a multiplication table is one more than the column left of it.

![The same table as above, with the columns labeled 8, 9, and 10 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/59e2b6915786a0c2c317b5ad387180665de0e14e)

$40 \stackrel{\maroonD{+5}}{\longrightarrow} 45 \stackrel{\maroonD{+5}}{\longrightarrow} 50$

The factor for the first row is $\maroonD{5}$.

![The same table as above, with the first row labeled 5.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5f77e66c615680c51f3ecc0a8c8649895251fc2a)

The factor for each row of a multiplication table is one more than the row above it.

![The same table as above, with the rows labeled 5, 6, and 7 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/adc9d197479dca3670de2d2f717e57bc8a9ad088)

Now we know the factors, so we can multiply to find the missing numbers.

$6 \times 8 = 48$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 6 and column 8 labeled 48.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/583cf387415c7e2467dbc82e10045be5412ba9c0)

$7 \times 9 = 63$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 7 and column 9 labeled 63.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/91d5bbeb043dd6434528c1d151bf0f2fd27919be)

Here is the completed pattern.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 40, 45, 50. The second row reads 48, 54, 60. The third row reads 56, 63, 70. !

question.content:
Part of a multiplication table is below.

**Complete the pattern in the multiplication table.**

[[☃ label-image 1]]

options.imageAlt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 40, 45, 50. The second row reads an unknown number, 54, 60. The third row reads 56, an unknown number, 70.

markers.label: The unknown number in the second row and first column
The unknown number in the third row and second column
